pros:
Location 
Watching the matinees 
Excellent Christmas parties

cons: Low salary, this could be higher considering location

review_title: I had a very bad experience there.
pros: Discounted show tickets Christmas Party
cons: Apart from the discounted tickets and a pretty good Christmas party there is little else. Senior management micromanage projects to the extent it causes conflict with suppliers. The line manager I had did not support me and HR are nothing more than a plight that would rather push you out than fix internal problems. They are pushing for improvements but will not invest in recruiting people to do it and instead makes those who work there work at a velocity that causes burn out. Their aim is to get more money from the customer rather than look after the staff they have which will push the efficiencies they need to make positive RoI. All if this is from a my own personal experience

job_title: IT Infrastructure Manager in London, England
pros: The Royal Opera House is a great place to work mainly for its workforce. People are passionate, supportive and very much engaged with this historic institution, contributing to a friendly and very diverse environment. Overall I believe this a great place to work, specially if you like classic arts like Opera and Ballet!
cons: It is a charity and salaries are not very high. Although some improvements have been done in the past couple of years I feel there are still inequalities on salaries based on the department you work for. Office spaces and areas are also not the greatest.

job_title: Cafe Barista in Covent Garden, England
pros: Weekly Pay, somewhat flexible work days
cons: Supervisors can be disrespectful manager have no care or regard for mental health overworked, a lot of micromanaging companies often ignored, no changes/improvements are made

review_title: Unfairly maligned - it's a tight ship!
job_title: Associate Production Manager in London, England
pros: - Amazing staff - Family atmosphere - Great cafe and canteen - Incredibly high artistic and operational standards - Amazing location
cons: - Salaries are not high. - Get ready to constantly defend the organisation for being fat-cat to ALL your friends... it just isn't true! It's incredibly tightly and efficiently run. - Really tough to get promoted - it's a proper 'dead-mans-shoes' situation. But that also shows how much people don't want to leave - they like it! - You don't see a lot of sunlight! - Long hours - it'd be tough to raise children

pros: Flexible hours, lunch included, cool building
cons: Micromanagement, unfair treatment, and condescending managers

review_title: developing a career in arts management (early stage of the career)
pros: l really enjoyed working for one of the renowned arts organisations in the UK which was a bonus for my CV in the early stages of my career. The colleagues were very friendly, too.
cons: Working in a large organisation as opposed to a smaller one means your role and responsibilities are clearly defined, so there was little flexibility to take on additional tasks. Having said that, I may have been too young to spot such opportunities.

pros: Staff discounts and access to performances.
cons: Low salary and no progression opportunities.

job_title: Receptionist/Box Office Assistant in Alpharetta, GA
pros: Easy access to cheap tickets. Beautiful place to work.
cons: HR is now only about saving their own skin. Managers have no clue about management. Lots of disabled staff were discriminated against

pros: Engaging when dealing with a variety of problems
cons: Workload gets a bit hectic sometimes

pros: Performance tickets, massive stage, Covent Garden location, busy atmosphere

pros: Lots of interesting tech to play with

pros: The team were amazing, really great at what they do and they cared about arts and young people

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Covent Garden, England
pros: Great place to work - wonderful people. A proper vision for how these art forms can stimulate people at all levels.
cons: The obvious constraints of being partially publicly funded and being a charity but, in the end, those are galvanising factors.

pros: Full of highly-skilled creative workers who are passionate about what they do.
cons: Management contains some really crazy individuals who provide poor leadership and thrive on creating tension between employees.

pros: If you love the arts it is an exciting place to work. There is something magic about working in an active theatre with world class performances. I enjoyed the occasional free tickets to rehearsals (although they are mainly during the work day). It's a gorgeous building, excellent location (easy commute), plus it's small enough company that you can get to know a broad range of people. The Christmas party was always a spectacle.
cons: Pay is not great. It's not a very diverse workplace (super white) but again I think that is not uncommon for this industry. There's literally no career development here. I can't think of any examples of promotion (in any department) that I am aware of. People tend to stay for years and years in one role and stagnate, so I'd say it's a great place to work for a while (1-2 years) to get some great experience, but don't expect to get a new job title or raise, or even the opportunity to apply, even if others above you leave. They don't seem to ever promote from within, always source new people from outside which is a shame.

pros: Cultural , Interesting setting, quite different, central london
cons: No idea about actual access, very clique, lower paid staff badly treated, quite average I guess

review_title: Good place if passionate about the arts
pros: Creative people, opportunities to see shows

job_title: Junior Business Analyst in London, England
pros: Everything was so so good!
cons: You are so awesome opera!

pros: so much fun, family atmosphere, every day is excitable, new thing's happening all the time, never know what's going to happen in the next half hour, thing's happen so fast you never have to watch the clock, and it's just fun, fun, fun, all daY LONG
cons: iv'e personally experienced somebody sending revenge porn of me into my colleagues in work whereupon they all took the path to keep it coming for a whole year, giggling at me and pointing the finger at me daily knowing how hurt i was, i'm now in deep depression   scared all day long on a daily basis and nobody in the company has thought of calling the police to help me

review_title: Very good employee care; highly political
pros: Incredibly friendly; no two days the same; staff feel like your family; promising culture of diversity,  inclusion and respect introduced; good standard benefits including good respect for work life balance in last few years.
cons:
A complex and intensely political organisation that's now also becoming increasingly corporatised and micro-managed. 
Excellent strides in last couple of years in offering career-insight opportunities.  However, they do not and never have had a culture of nurturing and promoting from within at more senior post levels, so unless you are in a vocational post, not a place to make a career. 

Also, despite great gender and ethnic diversity and inclusion, the staff environments are not disability friendly at all.

review_title: Life in the Royal Opera House Orchestra.
pros: Performing with the cream of International Singers and Conductors.Enjoying regular employment based in central London.Occasional trips abroad to the far east.USA etc.The best orchestral job in the UK.
cons: Operas are often very long so great stamina is needed from both Singers and Instrumentalists.If a key Singer or player is indisposed it can be very difficult to replace them at short notice.

pros:
Amazing opportunity to work in creative environment, and access to see world class performances for free

Near unrivalled resource and sector-leading standards

Strong and supportive HR structure

Vast majority of staff are extremely friendly and very engaged in the organisation's work

Increasingly progressive outlook and strategy

Iconic central London location
cons:
Opportunities for progression vary depending on department

Unbanded pay can see considerable variation between colleagues at same level

Occasional tension between old-school and progressive management styles

Complicated management structure, as with many large arts organisations

Takes three seasons of work to earn full holiday allowance - 20 days for first three seasons / 25 days thereafter.

review_title: Interesting and involving, who knew so much was involved in  producing world class opera and ballet.
pros:
Interesting and varied work
Great colleagues who are passionate about what they do. 
Great working in such iconic building in the heart of London
cons:
It's a charity so salaries are at the lower end of the scale. 
Doesn't seem to have any formal performance review processes in place.

pros: Total commitment to the creation of great operas at the highest level in a professional, friendly and safe work environment.
cons: Access and storage for bicycles could be improved.
